step_by_step_thinking: The patient presents with right flank pain, hypertension, and ultrasound findings of right ureter and renal pelvis dilation. Key considerations include causes of ureteral obstruction. Document 2 mentions retroperitoneal fibrosis can cause hydronephrosis via ureteral compression and is associated with renovascular hypertension, but this isn't an option. Document 7 links left renal vein obstruction to hypertension and ureteric colic, but the patient's right flank pain suggests a different cause. Common iliac artery aneurysm (option C) can compress the ureter, leading to dilation (Document 13 UMLS). Benign prostatic hyperplasia (B) might cause hydronephrosis but less directly. Renal artery stenosis (A) causes hypertension but not ureter dilation. Urethral stricture (D) affects the urethra, not the ureter. The most likely cause is common iliac artery aneurysm compressing the ureter.
